description.narrative:
1). % of legislation presented to the new national legislature with gender-responsive and inclusive provisions
2). # of CA/LP members, political party leaders and government officials have increased understanding on key constitutional issues and transition management
3). # option papers on key constitutional issues developed and discussed with CA members 4). # of general public and political leaders educate on constitutional issues through civic education programme 5). # of knowledge product published and distributed 6) # of journalist and lawyers trained 7). # interactions and intervention on gender and social inclusion issues

comment.narrative: Zero

1). NA 2). 30 dialogues/interaction workshops hosted on key constitutional issues 3). 3 Option Papers developed and shared with CA members and political leaders 4). Educate 8500 General public and local level stakeholders on key constitutional issues and 15000 public feedback to the CA on draft constitution 5). Two Knowledge product developed and distributed 7). 95 lawyers trained 8). 9 Interactions events on gender and social inclusion issues

The long awaited constitution was promulgated in September 2015. UNDP significantly contributed to the constitution making process as well as in the content. Since 2008, UNDP's Support to Participatory constitution Building Process in Nepal Project provided technical support to the constitution writing process through more than 10,000 dialogues, workshops, and interactions, more than 70 knowledge products inducing the option papers at national and local level. The purpose is to help increase the knowledge of the CA members to have informed debates and negotiate with evidence. This has helped to narrow the gap among political parties to reach consensus on various constitutional issues reflected in the new constitution. In order to ensure citizens’ participation in constitution making process, more than 600,000 people across the country were consulted and around 15,500 comments over the draft were collected through Facebook campaign and civil society outreach. Similarly, technical knowledge and leadership skills of women and excluded groups were enhance through more than 200 training, workshops, meetings and interactions organized by the UNDP over 7 years, which helped them to influence the constitution agenda in the CA. As a result, the new constitution sets out proportionate inclusion as one of its core principles and representation and fundamental rights of women and excluded groups . In 2015, following results achieved 1). NA 2). Gaps narrowed among the major political parties through 36 informed dialogues, interactions, meetings, and consultations on the constitutional issues, which contributed to promulgate the new constitution. For example: CPM (Maoist) party came into a consensus with other major political parties to resume constitution making process. It contributed to promulgate the new constitution 3). 2 Option Papers developed and shared with CA members and political leaders for informed debate. It helped to narrow the gaps among the leaders. 4). A tot

description.narrative: Selected civil society organisations supported to facilitate participation of excluded groups.
Support the Parliament as law making and oversight body.

1). Necessary laws on delimitation of competencies of local, provincial and national government in place 2) # of preliminary studies 3) A comprehensive need assessment completed 4) # of Parliamentarians and Parliament staffs trained 5) A framework for oversight function developed. 6) # of events for women, youth and other excluded groups 7) # of knowledge products 8) # of Bills reviewed by committees in participatory manner 9)# of oversight inquiries conducted by committees in an inclusive and participatory manner 10) # of people educated on new constitutional provisions

comment.narrative: Zero

1). NA 2) Two preliminary studies commissioned 3) 40 Parliamentarians trained 4) A Mock Youth parliament conducted 5) One knowledge product published and distributed 6) 1000 people educated on constitutional provisions of new constitution 7) Two Interaction events conducted for women and dalits to discuss the existing provisions of new constitution from women and dalit perspective

2) Two preliminary studies commissioned; 1) Mapping and Prioritizing Legislature-Parliament Committees and the Key Areas of Support Required by the Committees including the law review and formulations and 2). Parliament Outreach Strategy in Nepal. A comprehensive need assessment is planned for 2016.
3) 22 Parliamentarians trained on evaluation skills, which enhanced the knowledge of Parliament members on evaluation skills and helped them to perform their oversight functions effectively. Similarly, 22 women Parliamentarians trained on dealing with Media and communication skills. It helped to enhanced the skills of women Parliament members in order to deal with media and to make better communication during the Parliamentary debate at Parliament sessions and in the committee meetings. 4) A mock youth parliament conducted for 100 youths and debated on Federalism and quota system. It enhanced the knowledge of youth on constitutional issues. 5) One knowledge Product on civic education material on new constitutional provisions developed and widely circulated. 6) 1140 general public educated on constitutional provisions . 7). Two interaction events completed to review the existing provisions from women and dalit perspective, identifying gaps and ways forward. Those events helped to educate the civil society members on the provisions related to women and dalit in the new constitution. IN addition, it helped the Parliament members and civil society members to identify the areas to be addressed while formulating and reviewing the new policy and laws for the implementation of constitutional provisions related to women and dalits.

1)At least two bills reviewed and feedback submitted to Parliament members 2)2000 general public educated on constitutional provisions 3)Develop a framework for oversight function 4) A comprehensive need assessment 5) 5 Interaction meeting/workshop with the Parliamentary committees 6) Provide targeted support to the Chairs of the Parliamentary Committees (15) and Committee Secretaries (15) in policy analysis, law making, and instruments of undertaking effective oversight 7)Facilitate setting up of a group( loose forum) with special focus to fostering SDGs implementation in Nepal 8)Facilitate issues-focused interactions (at least 3 with each group) between parliamentarians and women, youth and other excluded groups representatives to enhance first-hand information sharing and follow up

Eleven Bills (Election-3, Constitutional Commissions-6, Disability-1 and wildlife -1) were reviewed and expert support extended at various levels of Committee work (public consultations, committee deliberations, discussion with stakeholders etc.). Such feedback were reflected in form of amendment proposals by the parliamentarians. More than 700 people (38% female) reached through 10 awareness events on the constitutional provisions. Aired 10 themes on the new constitutional provisions through 90 FMs and reached 15 million people across whole country. An oversight framework developed and shared with 13 committee members including 3 female and 10 senior secretariat staff. In addition, International Advisor shared the international best practices on oversight functions to the committee members and secretariat staffs. It helped them for performing their oversight functions. A comprehensive need assessment completed and project document revised on the basis of Need Assessment and feedback provided by the stakeholders Total of 6 interaction events completed with five Parliament Committees, namely: Development Committee (7 MPs including 2 Female and 7 parliament staff), Environment Committee ( 43 MPs including 20 Female and 10 parliament secretariat staff), Social Justice and Human Rights Committee (17 MPs including 8 female and 7 parliament secretariat staff), Finance committee ( 27 MPs including 4 Female and 2 Staffs) and Women, children, senior citizen and social welfare committee (14 MPs including 11 Female and 37 Civil society members including 12 Female working with people with Disability) . Conducted interaction event on oversight role of Parliament members and shared international best practices. Similarly, conducted three oversight visits for committees; Environment Protection Committee including chair and 8 members to visit religious site in Triveni, Nawalparasi in order to inquire about cabinet's reportedly controversial decision of granting land of

Develop a strategy plan for preparation of establishing parliaments at national and provincial level Organize 9 events for 100 MPs and 30 staff 15 Parliamentary Committee members and 10 secretariat staffs on Sustainable Development Goals and their role for implementation of SDGs. Review 6 bills Organize 2 training/ interaction event for MPs. Organize 3 mock youth parliament. Organize 6 oversight visits and public hearing

Seven bills ( Janajati commission, Dalit commission, Madhesi Commission, Social inclusion commission, Mushlim commission, Tharu Commission and Medical Education) were reviewed and expert support extended at various levels of Committee work (public consultations, committee deliberations, discussion with stakeholders etc). Such feedback were reflected in form of amendment proposals by the parliamentarians. More than 335 people (17 % female; Social groups representation- Dalit 6%, Janjati 17%, Madhesi 3 %, Mushlim 48%, Brahmin/ Chhetri 26 % ) participated in public consultation process on the bills. Supported for three oversight visits (1 by Finance Committee and 2 by Social Justice and Human Rights Committee of Parliament). MPs inspected the ongoing revenue collection mechanism of Bhairahawa Customs Office and interacted with media community as well and took stock of the critical issues in this office. Of the issues discussed were about cross-border dryport which was still not constructed by the Indian side, the missing traders (registered as a new trader but vanishing afterwards) evading the taxes, under-evaluation of the goods at customs check etc. MPs committed to take forward the issues for the government's attention and action. Likewise, Social Justice and Human Rights Committee reached out to the prison inmates and interacted with them. Inmates raised the issue of insufficient ration, daily allowance and poor health care system in jail. Visiting MPs pledged to look into the issues and instruct government to ensure minimum human rights standards in jail. Through a dozen of events on various thematic areas, more than 50 MPs and 10 Parliament Secretariat staffs had the first hand understanding of the issues and also enhanced their knowledge. Four Mock Youth Parliament events were conducted during the reporting period, in which 491 youths ( 178 Male, 308 Female and 4 LGBTI; Social group representations : Dalit 7 %, Janajati 31 %, Brahmin/Chhetri 61 %, Madhesi 2 %

Nepal Climate Change Support Programme to build climate resilience in 14 districts in Mid-Western and Far-Western districts in Nepal
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
total number of national/sub-national development and key sectorial plans that explicitly address DRM and/or CRM
total number of budgeted national/sub-national development and key sectorial plans that explicitly address DRM and/or CRM
number of national/sub-national development and key sectorial plans that explicitly address DRM and/or CRM which are gender responsive
seat of a third-order administrative division
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness
Number of LAPA implemented and monitored

comment.narrative: No Local Adaptation Plan of Action Implemented.

(1) 800 additional LAPA priority local adaptation actions implementation (2) Creation of 95,000 person days employment (3) Capacity building of 10,000 participants (4) Capacity development for building institutional mechanisms of district bodies

UNDP supported implementation of 873 priority local adaptation actions in 14 districts to reduce vulnerabilities of 78,717 people, creation of 95,786 person days (29% women) of employment, mitigating disaster risks increased agricultural productivity by building structural measures improved irrigation. 10,838 participants were trained 13,635 were oriented on local adaptation action mitigating disaster risk. Institutional mechanisms of district bodies are capacitated made functional by institutionalizing of local adaptation planning in 90 VDCs 7 Municipalities (N1).

(1) Implementation of 512 local adaptation plan of actions (2) Organise orientation and trainings to district/VDC/municipality stakeholders on CCA, GESI and M/E (69 events) (3) Continued support to MoPE in policy and international commitment areas (NAP, INDC, Climate Financing)

(1) 732 prioritized local adaptation plan of actions implemented in 87 VDCs and 9 municipalities of 14 districts in far and mid-western region of Nepal benefitting 180,164 people. 890 metallic stoves and 1510 improved cooking stoves were distributed to the 2400 poor and vulnerable households. 45,910 meters of irrigation canals were constructed and maintained covering altogether 158 sites, irrigating additional 744.7 hectares of land. 15 plastic ponds, 64 rain water harvesting tanks, 406 normal ponds with a total capacity over 1.91 million litres were built to conserve water for irrigation purposes as well as household uses. 538 drinking water taps and 225 drinking water tanks with 912,197 litres of water storage capacity were built to serve additional 4,522 households to access clean water facilities. 34 elevated taps, 10 elevated toilets and 2 elevated safe grounds were built in flood prone areas.
(2) Orientation and training to district / VDC /municipality stakeholders on CCA, GESI and M/E (69 events) organised (3) Support provided to Ministry of Population and Environment in policy and international commitment areas (NAP, INDC, Climate Financing)

title.narrative: Community Based Flood and Glacial Lake Risk Redcution

description.narrative: Reduce human and material losses from Glacial Lake Outburst Flood (GLOF) events in Solukhumbu District and catastrophic flooding events in the Tarai and Churia Range of Nepal

title.narrative: Community Based Flood and Glacial Lake Risk Redcution
Community Based Flood and Glacial Lake Risk Redcution
Community Based Flood and Glacial Lake Risk Redcution

description.narrative: The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
Number of end-to-end early warning systems for man-made crisis and all major natural hazards (e.g. geo-physical and climate-induced hazards)
Output 7.3.2 Reduction of water level in Imja glacier lake and risk mitigation measures adopted in four most vulnerable Tarai districts
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

At least 100% of the population (men and women) who are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts within the 27 high risk settlements GLOF Impact Zone are covered by a comprehensive community-based Early Warning System (CBEWS)

comment.narrative: More than 31,862 people live in the high risk settlements of Imja GLOF Impact Zone and are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts. They have no EWS. Other forms of disaster preparedness are also limited.

GLOF preparedness at Imja Lake and Khumbu region through (i) installation of Community Based Early Warning Systems (CBEWS), (ii) logistic support to Evacuation Centers and (iii) formation of 12 Task Forces at vulnerable settlements implemented.
Flood preparedness implemented through installation of CBEWS in the Five river basins in Terai and through conduction of Flood Risk Management trainings.

Based on the recommendation received from Hazard Mapping and Safety and Evacuation Plan (H/SEP), evacuation centers have been strengthened; taskforces have been formed and operationalized and CBEWS equipment have been installed in 15 strategic locations – manual gauges; hand operation sirens and hand mikes under component I. A set of different activities such as street dramas, mock drills, trainings, production and dissemination of Information, Education and Communication (IEC) materials, GLOF risk reduction preparedness issues in communities and further institutionalization of risk reduction knowledge and skills.
Major milestones have been achieved in the construction of structural measures for flood risk reduction i.e. 4.4 Km embankment with gabion revetment work and bioengineering, 4.5 km Flood Proofing Drainage System (FDPS) and 6 Elevated Tube Wells (ETWs) have been constructed along with 18 Community Based Early Warning System (CBEWS)/ Community Based Flood Early Warning System (CBFEWS) have been installed under component II. A significant achievement has been made in terms of institutionalization of Sediment Monitoring Protocols (SMP). As such, the SMP has been published and disseminated as a major knowledge product by project. Furthermore, a national level training for the officials from DHM, DWIPD, DSCWM and President Churia Madhesh Terai Conservation Development Board (PCMTCDB) on Flood Hazard and Sediment Modeling has been conducted to further institutionalize the methodologies and techniques of sediment monitoring as per SMP.

1: Controlled drainage to reduce lake water by 3 meters in the Imja Glacial Lake completed. 2: Automated GLOF early warning system installed and made operational which will support to institutionalize the information dissemination of GLOF warnings and climate induced disasters through DHM website; institutionalization of Task forces and operationalization of community based early warning systems 3: Construction of embankment in five river basins and strengthening of evacuation centers in three targeted districts will be completed in Terai working districts. 4: Awareness raising activities on flood preparedness and institutionalization of knowledge products through collaborating partners including capacity building of Community Disaster Management Committees and Village Disaster Risk Management Committees undertaken.

description.narrative: To reduce human and material losses from Glacier Lake Outburst Flooding GLOF in Solukhumbu District and catastrophic flooding events in the Tarai and Churia Range

Number of high risk settlements of the GLOF Impact Zone of Solukhumbu district downstream of Imja lake area covered by an Early Warning System EWS refer to AMAT 1212
Number of institutions with increased capacity to minimize human and material losses from potential GLOF events in the High Mountains and climaterelated flooding in the Tarai and Churia Range refer to AMAT 221

comment.narrative:
As per the updated Baseline developed by the project Within 50 km downstream from the Imja Glacial Lake mainly covering 4 VDCs among which Khumjung Namche Chaurikharka lies in SNP Buffer Zone and adjoining Juving VDC which lies outside the buffer zone are identified as vulnerable VDCs Altogether 40 settlements having 3278 households with 12690 population which lie in 4 VDCs were identified as vulnerable from Imja GLOF
Primary beneficiaries 4360 population residing in permanent settlements with critical risk of GLOF
Secondary Beneficiaries 12690 residing along 50 km downstream from Imja Lake in 40 permanent settlements This includes the 4360 primary beneficiaries as well
Tertiary Beneficiaries Annual floating population 74992 24994 tourist 49998 porters and VDC people residing along the trekking route and Imja Khola and Dudhkoshi River
Total Beneficiaries A total of 87682 population including permanent residents and annual floating population in the area
The initial estimation of total beneficiaries was only 31862 However the study conducted by project on GLOF Hazard Zonation and Safety Evacuation Plan explored that the total of 87682 people will be benefited from the GLOF risk reduction activities in Khumbu region Thus project will be using the updated data instead of the numbers reported in project document
Infrastructure 55 km road 94 km trail 25 truss and suspension bridges 05 river embankment 05 irrigation canal three schools four office buildings 137 hotels 64 teashops three temple gumba and mosque two hydropower dam five water mills seven transmission lines and one industry
Total direct indirect costs of potential GLOF damages including replacement of major infrastructure estimated as 898 billion
Weak system for flood risk management only construction work is done in DWIDP
There is only a district level Disaster Relief Committee though no GLOF risk management committee formed in Solukhumbu district
DDRC is mostly involved in rescue and relief for post disaster work and their activity in the targeted districts is limited
Limited trained staff in DHM to work in GLOF risk reduction

By the end of the project at least 100 of the population men and women who are directly vulnerable to GLOF impacts within the 27 high risk settlements GLOF Impact Zone are covered by a comprehensive CommunityBased Early Warning System CBEWS
By the end of the project targeted trainingon the job training in gender sensitive flood risk management including disaster preparedness will have been provided to at least 32 technical staff from 2 key government departments DHM 2 senior level and DWIDP 30 district and regional level 30 representatives from 5 DDRCs 64 representatives from 1 GLOF Risk Management Committee and at least 2 university students
DHM will have the necessary technologies skills systems to assess and effectively communicate GLOF risk levels and warnings
DWIDP will have the necessary technologies skills systems to monitor sediment load in floodprone river basins in the Tarai Churia Range
The Annual District Plans of at least 3 of the 5 target project districts incorporate budgeted flood risk preparedness activities

Twelve Taskforces each containing three subgroups of search and rescue first aid and early warning have been formed during March 2015 in project area All Taskforces have been equipped with necessary First Aid FA Light Search and Rescue LSAR and Community Based Early Warning System CBEWS equipment and trained total 152 members on use of equipment during GLOF and any climatic hazards on June 2015
CBEWS have been installed in 15 identified locations along the 50 km stretch downstream from Imja during June 2015
First round of training on Flood Risk Management and Sediment Monitoring was organized during 1821 August 2014 at Lahan for district level officers Another training was organized during 1720 November 2014 for national level officials As a followup of first round training on Flood risk management and sediment monitoring is planned for third quarter 2015
Sediment Monitoring Protocols for Churia Originating River Systems was developed and shared to DHM DWIDP and DSCMW which aims toward internalizing the Protocols in their sediment database management system

description.narrative: Human and material losses from recurrent flooding events in 4 floodprone districts of the Tarai and Churia Range reduced

Number of additional people provided with access to safe water supply and basic sanitation services
refer to AMAT 123
Number of people and value of their material assets covered by a CBEWS in the four target project districts
refer to AMAT 2221 3111 3211
Number of targeted institutions with increased capacity to minimize exposure to flood risks in the Tarai Churia Range
refer to AMAT 2211 3211

comment.narrative:
Existing tube wells in 8 VDCs get flooded during the flooding season hindering the access to safe drinking water for 59062 population residing in the villages
Water supplydrainage system in 8 VDCs gets flooded making it difficult for 59062 population
The initial estimation of the population for six VDCs which get flooded during the flooding season was 22500 Likewise the population estimation of four VDCs in which water supplydrainage get flooded in monsoon was 14500 However the detail study carried out by the project called Project related Baseline SocioEconomic data of Eight Project covering VDCs of Terai and Churia Region came up with the updated number ie 59062 population from total eight VDCs will be beneficiaries of the project Thus project will be using the updated data instead of the numbers reported in project document
There are no EWS in the 4 project target districts 3 VDCs Mahisthan Hattilet and Aurahi communities in Mahottari district Janagha River have been trained in CBEWS UNDPCDRMP programme
The total population of the most floodprone VDCs is 59062
Weak system for flood risk management DWIDP currently focuses only on construction works
Limited trained staffs in DWIDP on flood risk management
DDRC is mostly involved in rescue and relief for post disaster work and their activity in the targeted districts is limited

At least 70 population in 3 districts6 VDCs have access to 24 elevated tube wells andor a flood proofing drainage system
100 of the population covered by CBEWS in all target flood prone river basins
By the end of the project at least 8 gender sensitive Village Disaster Management Plans prepared by the Village Disaster Risk Management Committees in the Terai Churia Range
By the end of the project at least two vulnerable VDCs of four districts will have CBEWSs and which are being effectively maintained by local communities including women under the leadership of the Village Management Committees

35 Elevated Tube Wells were constructed in the four districts8 target VDCs Hence this ensures about 75 population have access to safe drinking water during flood
About 45 km long Flood Proofing Drainage System has been constructed by the end of June 2015
Total of eight Village Disaster Risk Management Committees VDRMCs and 35 Community Disaster Management Committees CDMCs have been formed and operationalized during July 2014 A total of 399 members are affiliated in 35 CDMCs including 200 female and 199 male
Altogether 28 FA Taskforces and 27 LSAR Taskforces have been formed under CDMCs and operationalized during July 2014 Likewise 23 CBEWS Taskforces have been formed during March 2015
Taskforces were equipped with relevant equipment during March 2015
Training on LSAR and FA to members of Taskforces have been conducted during June 2015 A total of 213 members were trained including 87 female
A total of 44 District and national level officials from DWIDP and DSCWM have been trained on Flood Risk Management Sediment Monitoring during August and November 2014 respectively
Training on Mainstreaming Flood Risk Management in Development Planning Process was also conducted to VDC level officials during August 2014

description.narrative: Risks of human and material losses from Glacial Lake Outburst Flooding GLOF events from Imja Lake reduced

Average depth of Imja lake
refer to AMAT 1212
Percentage of high risk settlements of Imja GLOF Impact Zone residents including women children and elderly people with a clear understand of how the EWS works and what to do in the event of a GLOF
refer to AMAT 2121 3111
Number of targeted institutions with increased capacity to minimize exposure to GLOF risks
refer to AMAT 2211 2221 23112 3211

comment.narrative:
Updated baseline data Average water depth of Lake is 588 m and highest water depth was 1498 m in October 2014
90 of the community have heard about GLOF about GLOF risk but are not prepared for it Source Regional GLOF Risk Reduction Project
X number of female and Y number of male are aware of the potential risk of GLOF and benefits of EWS
No local institution to address or understand the GLOF risk which is creating unnecessary havoc of outburst
Limited access to information as well as Government level institution in the Khumbu region Imja lake and surrounding to address or disseminate GLOF risks

Average depth of lake kept below danger level by ensuring average water depth during spring and summer months is at least 3 meters or more below the baseline level prior to the construction of the channel
100 residents from Solukhumbu district of the high risk settlements of the GLOF Impact Zone within 50 km of outlet understand how the EWS works and know what to do during the event of a GLOF including men and women and elder residents
Number of representatives from Solukhubmu DDRC Sagarmatha National Park the Imja GLOF Risk Management Committee and CBEWS Taskforces trained to manage and minimize GLOF risks
No type of information materials disseminated to local and nonlocal people ie tourists by different agencies on GLOF risks risk reduction measures and what to do in the event of a GLOF
By the end of the project DHM is operating a GLOF Risk Monitoring System and has a mechanism in place to communicate GLOF risk warnings to MoHA and NEOC

Lake lowering design and other associated studies such as Electric Resistivity Tomography ERT Ground Penetrating Radar GPR investigation and Bathymetric survey of the lake were completed on December 2014 Based on these studies the design for lake lowering was completed in the first quarter 2015
Invitation to Bid ITB to undertake the construction activities of lake lowering has been announced
12 Taskforces consisting of early warning FA and LSAR subgroups have been formed along the stretch of 50 km downstream from the Imja lake under the umbrella of GMRCC during March 2015
20 Local Resource Persons LRPs consisting of 13 male and 7 female members have been developed and trained on GLOF risk management Training of Trainer ToT in 2014
CBEWS tools and equipment have been handed over to Taskforce and training to handle and equipment use was organized during June 2015
Mobile Apps to disseminate information related to GLOF risk reduction has been developed during January 2015 Communication medium IRIDUM system is being extended by GovernmentPrivate in the project site after which this apps will be functional operational
Study on automatic Imja GLOF EWS with cost effective data transfer from equipment at Imja Lake to local community and DHM web portal was completed during December 2014

description.narrative:
1) % increase in the execution of court decisions
2) National Legal Aid Policy is in place 3) # of women and vulnerable communities benefited from legal aid 4) # of JSCC secretariats established and operational 5) # of information centers established and operational 6) Joint monitoring group established and investigation system strengthened 7). # of laws reviewed and submitted for the passage 8) # of MOJ officials trained on legislative drafting and treaty negotiations

comment.narrative:
1) 11 % prison sentences enforced and 8% increase in the number of civil court decisions (2012)
2) No policy on legal aid is in place

I) # of Socio-legal aid centers established and fully operational ii) 2 : # of women and vulnerable benefited from legal aid service; iii) # of government officials enhanced knowledge and skills on legislative drafting and negotiation; iii) National Legal Aid policy in place and endorsed by MoLJCAPA ; iv) # of Training manual/reference material/ guideline/policy developed; v) # of software developed and endorsed on judgment execution application registration (Dhauti and Jetha, Dasi ko Saman and Calendar system); vi) judgment execution increased by X% in programme districts; vii) # of student received scholarship for BA/LLB; viii) # of new law graduated received legal internship and BA/LLB curriculum of TU revised with new update and # of TU personnel oriented on new curriculum

1) Socio-legal aid centers established in additional 5 districts; ii) (a) 4843 benefitted from remedial; (b) 38794 benefitted from preventive services; iii) Legal aid policy drafted and being finalized; iv) Training manual for paid lawyer system and guideline on law review developed; v) (a) 22.96% in fine; (b) 26.8% in prison (JED Report, 2071-72); vi) 30 interns enrolled and curricula revised on gender-social inclusion and human rights

(1) 10000 women and vulnerable people benefited by legal aid services, (2) 75 legal aid clients achived outcomes in their favor, 3) 2 outdated laws revises; 4) 100 justice sector officials received training on penal code and criminal procedurals; 5) 5000 court clients benefited from the services of court system and information center; 6) 10 events of innovative actions organized by district JSCC; 7) 40 new layers received internship; 8) 100 legal aid lawyers received training

1) Total 6862 (including 4144) people benefitted from remedial legal aid service; 14,214 (including 7650) people benefitted from preventive service; (2) Total 94 legal aid clients achieved legal outcomes in their favor in court decision; 3) 10 legislations reviewed [i.e. 5 Codes 5 Acts on Rights to Privacy, Food, Dalit Commission, National Women Commission, Anti-CBDU Act); 4) Total 536 (including 92 female) court officials oriented on penal code and criminal procedurals; 5) Total 29710 court clients (including 10,934 female) benefitted from the services of court system information desk in 23 working districts: 6) Total 46 innovative events (actions) organized by 23 district JSCC for strengthening JSCC coordination mechanism; 7) Total 40 new law graduates completed internship support; and enrolled in legal profession; 8) Total 401 legal aid lawyers (including 68 female) received training on providing legal aid services in district level

description.narrative: Renewable Energy for Rural Livelihood (RERL) project focuses on off-grid renewable energy technologies to promote income generating opportunities and a low-carbon development path in rural areas of Nepal.
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
Number of new development partnerships with funding for improved energy efficiency and/or sustainable energy solutions targeting underserved communities/groups and women
total number of people with improved access to energy as a result of UNDP-supported intervention
Output 2.4.1 Alternative Energy Promotion Center's (AEPC) capacity enhanced for scaling up energy services in the rural areas.

a) Total installed capacity of renewable energy-based power generation projects implemented by end-of-project (EOP) in MW
b) Electricity generated annually for livelihood and quality of life improvement (GWh/yr) by the EOP.

comment.narrative: a) Draft RE Policy Document Prepared b) 3,000 additional households connected to energy services c) Undertake 100 Micro-Hydro Rapid Assessment destroyed by April Earthquake d) Install 10 solar energy solutions to public institutions destroyed by April Earthquake

a) RE policy finalization is in the process. A stakeholder (DPs, line ministries, private sector etc.) consultation for RE policy has been conducted. Based on the feedback, GON/AEPC has prioritized to revise subsidy policy and delivery mechanism prior to the RE policy, as it was deemed important and relevant. RERL provided assistance to AEPC to draft Renewable Energy Subsidy Policy 2015. The final draft has been prepared and submitted to the line Ministry after consultations with AEPC, Development Partners (DPs), concerned government agencies and private sector. The new draft policy encourages private participation and PPP model in the RE sector. It also goes beyond the current practice of providing subsidy for equipment and includes provision for subsidizing services. The finalization of RE policy has now been pushed to next year. b) AEPC supported 3,581 households to connect to electricity with the support of RERL and NRREP (1,776 households directly connected by RERL and 1,805 households connected by NRREP with technical support from RERL). c) 100 MH Rapid Assessment completed and 40 additional rapid assessment ongoing. d) Installed 33 solar energy solutions to public institutions by RERL destroyed by April Earthquake and technically supported AEPC to install additional 9 solar energy solutions to public institutions.
30 kW solar PV Systems installed; 600 kW rehabilitation of earthquake affected MHPs; financial closure of 500 kW mini hydro completed

(1) Altogether 31.2 kW solar PV systems were installed (16.6 kW , Institutional Solar in ... Health Posts through Relife and Rehabilitation activity benefitting 36,121 HHs from + Dhading solar mini grid 4 kW, 46 HHs + Solar Pumping 2.6 kW, 46 HHs + Solr Micro Industrial Hub 4 kW, 43 HHs +Telkuwa Solar Pumping 4 kW, 29 HHs . Total beneficiary HHs si 36,285 ) (2) 43 MHPs with the total capacity of 2,045 kW benefiting 17,613HHs (26 MHPs with 662 kW capapcity benefitting 6,617 HHs by rehabilitation works and 17 MHPs with capacity of 1,383 kW benefitting 10,996 HHs by NRREP) 17,688 HHs directly benefit from access to electricity and 36,210 households benefit from electricity access to their Health Posts, VDC/DDC Offices and Schools/Temporary Learning Centers. 253,320 people from 53,898 households benefit from energy services. (3) Financial closure of 200 kW initiated

description.narrative: SE4ALL Capacity Building Proposal for NPC

- SE4ALL Country Action Agenda approved by the Government - SE4ALLInvestment Prospectus finalized for submission to the Government. - Establishment of SE4ALL Secretariat formalized within NPC; Secretariat is led by an officer level NPC staff; Secretariat is serving as the contact point for all SE4ALL related activities - SE4ALL Secretariat staff are knowledgeable about SE4ALL objectives and implementation status worldwide and in Nepal; SE4ALL Secretariat is leading and coordinating all SE4ALL activities

comment.narrative: Not there
1. First Draft of SE4ALL National Action Agenda prepared 2.SE4ALL Country Action Agenda finalized in consultation with Government of Nepal and Donor Partners

First draft of SE4ALL National Action Agenda is prepared and is circulated for feedback with Government agencies, development partners, private sector and civil society who are part of SE4ALL coordination mechanism. In December the draft document is being consulted individually and in a wider forum with the relevant stakeholders towards finalization.

1: SE4ALL Country Action Agenda finalized in consultation with Government of Nepal and Donor Partners.
2: Investment Prospectus for energy sector finalized in consultation with relevant stakeholders.

1: Country Action Agenda on going; Capacity building of government officials regarding SE4ALL completed; Orientation for civil society and private sector on SE4ALL will be completed by December 2016
2: Draft TOR prepared to hire consultant team to initiate the work.
